Award.AwardTitle: A reliable and scalable approach to causal inference for large-scale multivariate data
Award.AbstractNarration:
With masses of large-scale data being generated, a key challenge facing many scientists is to infer relationships amongst variables of interest. In particular, inferring causal or functional relationships amongst genes, proteins, and other biological elements is of fundamental interest to scientists. This project will develop methods for inferring causal or functional relations between genetic, proteomic, and transcriptomic features both for the ENCODE human genome project and data for mice with different susceptibility to obesity and diabetes. For both types of data, this project will develop frameworks that comprise: (1) domain knowledge that informs the choice of model and algorithm; (2) fast, parallelizeable algorithms with provable run-time guarantees; and (3) statistical consistency guarantees for the algorithms developed under assumptions that are likely to be satisfied in practice.

Directed graphical models or Bayesian networks provide a useful framework for representing causal or functional relationships. A number of algorithms have been developed for inferring directed or Bayesian networks from data. However prior approaches are either unreliable as they require assumptions that are rarely satisfied in practice, or do not scale to larger datasets. The proposed project will address this issue by developing algorithms for inferring directed networks with both statistical consistency guarantees and run-time guarantees. The new algorithms will involve exploiting connections between techniques in numerical linear algebra for developing fast solvers of linear systems and concepts in graph theory. Algorithms will be coded in R and will exploit parallel processing. Evaluation will involve both small-scale and large-scale synthetic graphical models with known network structure, real datasets involving yeast data where some of the directions are known, and new biochemistry data in which most of the directions are unknown. Theoretical guarantees on run-time and statistical consistency will be provided using a combination of tools from graph theory, numerical linear algebra, and concentration of measure the PI has used and developed in prior work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

During the period of this grant, Raskutti and his students have developed a number of new methods and supporting performance gaurantees for learning causal relationships for multi-variate high-dimensional models. He has also applied these to problems in biochemistry and computational neuroscience.

In particular, PI Raskutti and former PhD student Gunwoong Park have addressed a number of identifiability and computational challenges associated with discrete directed graphical models, casual graphical models with feedback loops, and in an on-going project combining observational and experimental data in a sequential experimental design framework. Work conducted by PI Raskutti with Gunwoong Park has led to his Park's graduation in July 2016 and he will being a post-doctoral fellowship at University of Michigan.

PI Raskutti was also a co-advisor (with Professor Ming Yuan) of PhD student Han Chen who graduated in 2016 and lead to new statistical and computational guarantees for high-dimensional tensor network models, which account for higher-order interaction structure and this work led to the graduation of Chen in June 2017. In addition, PI Raskutti developed new estimation procedures and theoretical guarantees for temporal Granger causality networks for multi-variate point process data in porjects with (Professor Rebecca Willett) and PhD students Eric Hall and Benjamin Mark.

PI Raskutti has developed packages for the methods described above and has begun to use these methods on important problems in biochemistry and computational neuroscience. In particular, Raskutti has adapted the causal graphical model learning approacch to learning direct coupling analysis networks for important proteins in biochemistry in a project with PhD student Hyebin Song and Biochemistry professor Philip Romero. In addition, PI Raskutti is working with Professor Willett (ECE) and PhD student Benjamin Mark on using the Granger causality network framework for learning functional connectivity networks for the brain.

Broader impacts

PI Raskutti has developed a number of successful collaborations with Professors in Biostatistics, Philosophy and Electrical Engineering based on the projects undertaken in the grant.

Further, PI Raskutti currently mentors three PhD students in Statistics, Yuan Li, Hyebin Song, Lili Zheng and a PhD student in Mathematics Benjamin Mark and two undergraduate students, Yuan Ma and David Niemann. Raskutti has previously mentored PhD students Gunwoong Park (graduated 2016) and co-adivised Han Chen (graduated 2017). 

Raskutti has developed 2 new graduate level courses based on the work developed using the NSF grant mentioned above. Raskutti taught Stat 992 in Spring 2015, which attracted 20 students, called “Graphical Models,” the only Graphical models course taught ever at UW Madison. The class attracted PhD students from Statistics, Computer Science, Engineering, Psychology, Philosophy and a number of other fields. Additionally in Fall 2015, Raskutti taught an undergraduate and Masters level course also on causal graphical models course that has attracted 20 Masters and early year PhD students from Statistics, Psychology and Sociology students from the University. Due to the interest in the course, the enrolment was doubled and in Spring 2016, PI Raskutti taught a graphical network models course with 50 students from departments across campus.

Modified by: Garvesh Raskutti
